div.p: The present documents reflect a small sample of the corpus known as the Jasper N. Bertram papers. These papers contain an eclectic mix of letters, newspaper clippings, business documents, greeting cards, pamphlets, personal correspondences, and notes. The documents are printed, typewritten, and handwritten; some contain a mix of text types. The archive within the University of Washington Special Collections provides a brief biographical overview of Jasper N. Bertram's life.

While these documents represent a small fraction of the materials present within the archive of Jasper N. Bertram, we hope to attach this TEI encoding to the archival record so that it may aid in distribution and availability of these materials digitally. The duration of Jasper N. Bertram's life encompasses a critical time in our nation's history, from the Civil War, through the Industrial Revolution and the First World War, to his death during the Roaring Twenties. The chosen documents provide readers with a unique historical perspective of an individual with interests rooted in Seattle and beyond.

In an effort to preserve authorial intent of manuscript documents, we have chosen to leave all spelling and grammatical errors unedited. This choice was made in order for our edition to reflect authorial voices of the various persons represented in this collection, and the time period in which the documents were written. The excerpts chosen represent the interests of the editors while also serving to present a sample of multiple document types found throughout the collection.

We have recieved and filled your claim with the proper offi-
cial of the Government, and will prosecute it to a final settlement.

Prior to June 6, 1900, attorneys' fee were deducted and
paid them by the Government upon the allowance of claims, but this
practice in reagrd to fees as follows:

"Provided, That in the settlement of claims of officers,
soldiers, sailors, and marines, of their representatives,
and all other claims for pay and allowances within the jurisdiction
of the Auditor for the
War Department or the Auditor for the Navy Department, presented and filed hereafter in which it is
the present practice to make deductions of attorneys' fees from
the amound found due, no deductions of fees for attorneys or
agents shall hereafter be made, but the draft, check or warrant
for the full amount found due shall be delivered the payee
in person or sent to his bona fide post office adress (residence
of place of business.)"

Under this act fees are held to be a matter of adjust-
ment between claimants and attorneys, and the Government does not
now deduct and pay fees to attorneys as formerly in any of the above
described claims filed since the Act of Congress approved June 6,
1900.

The former practice of the Government in deducting and
paying the attorney fees upon settlement with the claimants was
greatly preferred by us, but the law javing changed this method as
stated, we are obliged to meet the new order of things.

You will, therefore, please remit us the sum of two dollars
($2) immediately upon receipt of this letter, to be applied to the
fee in your case, for bounty pay and other dues.
We must ask that you comply with this request at once!

No John Green has never been

I have never seen your discharge

before you came here
We shall be so proud if you

will stop with us
on your way to Washington
we shall expect it and
write us at once or as Soon

Diphtheria is a bacterial respiratory illness that primarily affects children under 5. The disease was considered highly contagious and deadly during its height, at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th century. Before the first vaccine was created in the 1890s, 1 out of 10 children infected by the disease died. Although, the vaccine was not widely distributed until the 1920s. See the source on the history of Diptheria.

Dear sir: Through Dr. A.I. Mitchell, I learn that you are interested
in the Chelan Country,and contemplate settling here. If you will write
me telling me just what you would like in the way of land and how
much you would care to invest I could answer your letter and tell you
whether such land could be
had att all and what the cost would be. You understand we have a fine fruit country and that tha country is
rough or rolling .We have also a fine country and few extremes of eithe
rheat or col.Reinquishments and homesteads are practically gone.I can s
sell you a 40 close to town and atv $20. an acre. Out of this 40 there
is 25 acres of the best of fruit land and the balance is pasture.No
improvements.This land joins Lakeside on the
south and is on teh first bench above. It is within reach of the town and hangs ovre the hill
A person could live in Lakeside if they wish and farm it. I would be
glad to hear from you on the subject and will furnish you any information you may wish.

body.p:
Sir:
I have examined your appeal, filed January 9, 1909, from the action
of the Auditor for the war Department, on your claim
for additional bounty under act of July 28, 1866, as of 9th
Regt. of Kentucky Infantry,
per certificate No. 20392, dated June 15, 1908,
and find and certify no differences, the action of the Auditor being affirmed.

It is shown by the records that you were enrolled
September 24, 1861, and discharged September 20, 1864, by
reason of promotion to lst Lieutenant. You have been paid
$100.00 bounty under act of July 22, 1861, and $50.00
additional bounty under act of July 28, 1866. Having been
discharged for promotion before serving three years as an
enlisted man you are not entitled to any more bounty.

Parol evidence will not be accepted to contradict the
records which show that you were enrolled September 24,
1861, and served less than three years as an enlisted
man. The time you served as a commissioned officer cannot
lawfully be counted in computing bounty.
body.closer: Respectfully, L.P. Mitchell J.W.R. Assistant Comptroller C.H.

div.head:
From Philadelphia "Record,"
An illustration of the Winston Building, described below.
August 6, 1903

div.p:
Workmen yesterday began the demolition of
the picturesque old Arch Street Presbyterian
Church, on Arch Street, above Tenth, whose site
is to be occupied by a large building for The John
C. Winston Company. The church has not been
used for several years, and its removal marks an
important step in the improvement of Arch
Street for commercial purposes. The inroads of
trade have driven out nearly all the residents
east of Broad Street, and west of that throrough-
fare they are also gradually being forced out.
The old church has long been admired for the
purity of its architecture, and its disappearance
will be regretted by many.

The new building which is to take its place
will be the largest on Arch street, and will
be eight stories high, with a frontage of 100 feet
and a depth of 150 feet. There will be an arcade driveway around the entire building, with room
for wagons to load in the read, under cover. The
building will be equipped with two freight eleva-
tors and a passenger elevator, fire-proof vaults
and other modern conveniences. It will have an
electrical power plant of 400-horse power, with
steam heating, electric lighting, etc. The buil-
ding will be of steel construction and semi-fire-
proof. The front will have a granite base, with
brick and terra-cotta above.

The contract price for the building, including
the power plant is $275,000. The value of the lot
is $150.000. The entire floor space of the build-
ing amounts to about 135,000 square feet, or about
three acres. The building will be completed in
July 1904, when The John C. Winston Company
will move into it their offices and printing and
binding plant.-Phila.Record.

div.head:
how a great publishing house has grown
out of a small beginning.
div.p:
The erection of a new and magnificent building, of such unusal size,
to accommodate our growing business, has awakened a great deal of
interest, and led to many inquiries regarding the history of our house.
For the information of those interested, and especially for the informa-
tion of agents and others in distant parts of the country who do business
with us, we present the following facts regarding the growth of our
business during the past twenty years.

In the fall of 1884 Mr. Winston began this business alone, on one
floor of a small building immediately opposite the site of our new building
on Arch Street. He began with the publication of one book, which
fortunately proved very successful. This book was sold by agents whom
Mr. Winston himself employed and trained. Encouraged by this first
success, Mr. Winston added one book after another and extended his
organization into many States, until his business became very extensive.

div.head: formation of the company.
div.p:
Realizing that a business of this size should not depend upon any one
man, Mr. Winston invited into partnership with him a number of able
and experienced men, and thus formed the present corporate company, with
an authorized capital of $500,000.

At first Mr. Winston had his books printed and bound by contract
with outside printers and binders, but many years ago this was found
inconvenient. Our present establishment consists of a large printing and
binding plant equipped with the best modern machinery.

div.head: the publication of bibles.
div.p:
Aside from the publication of several hundred popular books, many
of which have reached a sale of hundreds of thousands, The John C.
Winston Company publish what is known as the "International" line of
Bibles. This line of Bibles was originally published under the joint
management of two of the largest religious publication houses in the
United States. Our Company bought out this business, and has greatly
increased the line, until it now comprises over 500 styles of Bibles and
Testaments. It is said that we are the largest Bible publication house in
the United States, and certainly, taking into account our books and Bibles
together, we are the largest concern making this line of goods in the world.

div.head: our business acquaintance.
div.p:
While we do a very extensive business with agents on subscription
books, and have always made a specialty of this line of books, we are
to-day doing business all over the world, and are publishing books and
Bibles in English, French, German, Swedish, Norwegian and other
languages.

Any local banker or large merchant, having access to the usual
mercantile records, can satisfy any inquirer as to our general standing and
reliability. It is always easier to do business with those with whom you
are acquainted, and we desire to establish a feeling of confidence with all
those in correspondence with us, so that they may feel entire confidence
in any arrangement we may seek to make. If we have had marked and
unusual success in building up so large a business in a few years, from a
small beginning, we must attribute it chiefly to our facilities for helping
agents to succeed, because it has been the success of canvassers that has
brought about our own success and rapid growth.

The John C. Winston Co. are also proprietors of the Union Book and Bible House and the
Universal Book and Bible House, and are responsible for all contracts made by either of
these special departments.

person.note: "Jasper N. Bertram (1840-1928) was born in Wayne, Kentucky. He enlisted in the Civil War with the Kentucky Volunteers, 9th Regiment, 3rd Division, 1862-1864. He married Mary Ann Garrett on January 1, 1866, in Overton, Tennessee and they had five children. He was listed as a school teacher in Kentucky in 1873 and a Republican Party worker in 1882 in the 3rd Congressional District. After his first wife died in 1888, he moved to Seattle where he was district manager and salesman. He married Mary Huselby in 1896. He died on July 1, 1928 in Seattle, Washington." See the Jasper N. Bertram Papers.
